details.title: An Efficient Algorithm for Computing the Reliability of Consecutive-<formula formulatype="inline"><tex>$k$</tex></formula>-Out-Of-<formula formulatype="inline"><tex>$n$</tex></formula>:F Systems

authors.affiliation: Ecole Nat. Super. d'Ingenieurs de Limoges, Limoges

p: Thomas Cluzeau received a MS in 2000, and a PhD in 2003 both in Mathematics, and Applications from the University of Limoges (France). He is a member of the CANSO project of the DMI of XLIM (UMR CNRS 6172) from the university of Limoges. His research interests are in computer algebra, and applications.

authors.name: Thomas Cluzeau

p: Jörg Keller is an Associate Professor of computer science and engineering at FernUniversitaet, the German distance teaching university, since 1996. He received M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees in computer science in 1989, and 1992 from Saarland University, Saarbrücken, Germany, and has been an Assistant Professor there. His research interests are parallel processing, IT-security, and fault tolerance.

Winfrid G. Schneeweiss is a Professor Emeritus of computer engineering at FernUniversitaet, the German university for distance studies in Hagen. He is now the Manager of LiLoLe-Verlag (Publ. Co.), serving life-long learning especially in the field of reliability/safety modelling. See www.lilole-verlag.de for details of his books, and those of several colleagues. He earned a Diplom-Physicist degree from Frankfurt University in 1957, a Ph.D. degree from Munich Technical University in 1968, and his Habilitation for computer science from Karlsruhe University in 1973. He has published widely with emphasis on fault tree analysis, and Petri net design. He is a Senior Member of IEEE, and a member of several German engineering/scientific societies.

details.abstract: Many algorithms for computing the reliability of linear or circular consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems appeared in this Transactions. The best complexity estimate obtained for solving this problem is O(k<sup>3</sup> log(n/k)) operations in the case of i.i.d. components. Using fast algorithms for computing a selected term of a linear recurrence with constant coefficients, we provide an algorithm having arithmetic complexity O(k log (k) log(log(k)) log(n)+k<sup>omega</sup>) where 2<omega< 3 is the exponent of linear algebra. This algorithm holds generally for linear, and circular consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems with independent but not necessarily identical components.

references.title:
On the consecutive-<ref_formula><tex>$k$</tex>
</ref_formula>-<?Pub _newline?>out-of-<ref_formula><tex>$n$</tex></ref_formula>:F
system

context.text: The study of consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F systems has caught the attention of researchers since the early 1980s (see [1]–[7], and references therein).

If one now considers a circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F system, then the Boolean function of the fault tree becomes It is well known (see [4], [9], [11], [12], or [1], Theorem 2 for the case of identical components) that the unreliability \$U_{C}(n)\$ of the circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F system can be expressed as a linear combination of the \$U_{L}(m)\$ for \$n-k\leq m\leq n-1\$.

links.abstract: The linear (circular) k-of-n:F system has n linearly (circularly) ordered components. Each component either functions or fails. The system fails i.f.f.k consecutive components fail. This paper provides, in the i.i.d. case, recursive formulas and bounds for computing system reliability. It considers properties of system life distributions and, in the non i.i.d. case, questions of optimal system design.

references.text: C. Derman, G. J. Lieberman, S. M. Ross, "On the consecutive-\$k\$ -out-of-\$n\$:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-31, no. 1, pp. 57-63, Apr. 1982.

context.text: The study of consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F systems has caught the attention of researchers since the early 1980s (see [1]–[2][7], and references therein).

links.abstract: This paper develops a counting scheme for determining the reliability of a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F network. An example of such a network, a set of tables, and a comparative example are provided.

references.text: R. C. Bollinger, A. A. Salvia, "Consecutive-\$k\$ -out-of-\$n\$:F networks", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-31, no. 1, pp. 53-56, Apr. 1982.

context.text: The study of consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F systems has caught the attention of researchers since the early 1980s (see [1]–[3][7], and references therein).

links.abstract: A consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system, with n linearly or circularly arranged i.i.d. components is examined. The system reliability has an exact formula which is straight forward and more effective than those given elsewhere; the two formulas are given.

references.text: M. Lambiris, S. Papastavridis, "Exact reliability formulas for linear and circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of- \$n\$:F systems", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 34, no. 2, pp. 124-126, Jun. 1985.

references.title:
Survey of reliability studies of consecutive-<ref_formula>
<tex>$k$</tex></ref_formula>-out-of-<ref_formula><tex>$n$</tex></ref_formula>:F
and related systems

context.text: The study of consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F systems has caught the attention of researchers since the early 1980s (see [1]–[4][7], and references therein).
Classical examples are sequences of microwave stations, pump stations for transporting oil by pipes [4], or rows of street lanterns.

If one now considers a circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F system, then the Boolean function of the fault tree becomes It is well known (see [4], [9], [11], [12], or [1], Theorem 2 for the case of identical components) that the unreliability \$U_{C}(n)\$ of the circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F system can be expressed as a linear combination of the \$U_{L}(m)\$ for \$n-k\leq m\leq n-1\$.

links.abstract: The consecutive-k-out-of-n:F and related systems have caught the attention of many researchers since the early 1980s. The studies of these systems lead to better understanding of the reliability of general series systems, In computation and structure. This paper is mainly a chronological survey of computing the reliability of these systems.

references.text: M. T. Chao, J. C. Fu, M. V. Koutras, "Survey of reliability studies of consecutive- \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F and related systems", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 44, no. 1, pp. 120-127, Mar. 1995.

context.text: More precisely, people have been interested in computing efficiently the reliability of such systems in terms of the failure probabilities of each component (see [8]–[14], and references therein).

The unreliability of such systems can be expressed depending on the unreliability of systems with \$n-1,\ldots,n-k\$ components (see [8], Equation 1a. for example); this is straightforward by using probability arguments, but we show here that the corresponding linear recurrence equation of order \$k\$ can be recovered using Shannon decomposition [16].

This linear recurrence, given in Lemma 2 below, can be obtained directly using probability arguments (see [8], Equation 1a.); we propose here another approach using Shannon decomposition (see [16] for example).
Computing the expected value for stochastically independent components, we get [8], Equation 1a. the following lemma.

links.abstract: The previous literature on consecutive-k-out-of-n: F systems gives recursive equations for the system reliability only for the special case when all component reliabilities are equal. This paper gives recursive equations for the more general case when the component reliabilities can be different from each other. Furthermore, reliabilities can be computed more quickly from these recursive equations than those previously given.

references.text: F. K. Hwang, "Fast solutions for consecutive- \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-31, pp. 447-448, Dec. 1982.

links.abstract: A recursive algorithm obtains the reliability of a circular consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system. This algorithm works faster than those previously published.

references.text: I. Antonopoulou, S. Papastavridis, "Fast recursive algorithms to evaluate the reliability of a circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of- \$n\$:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-36, pp. 83-84, Apr. 1987.

references.title:
A direct algorithm for computing reliability of a consecutive-<ref_formula>
<tex>$k$</tex></ref_formula> cycle

context.text: More precisely, people have been interested in computing efficiently the reliability of such systems in terms of the failure probabilities of each component (see [8]–[10][14], and references therein).

links.abstract: A consecutive-k cycle is a circular system such that the system fails if and only if any i consecutive components all fail. Reliabilities for consecutive-k cycles are usually computed by recursive equations. However, most recursive equations proposed so far for the cycle involve reliabilities for consecutive-k lines, requiring two passes where the first pass computes only the line reliabilities. A recursive equation involving cycles only is proposed that is simpler in form but much harder to und...

references.text: D. Z. Du, F. K. Hwang, "A direct algorithm for computing reliability of a consecutive- \$k\$ cycle", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-37, pp. 70-72, Apr. 1988.

links.abstract: I. Antonopoulou and S. Papastavridis (1987) published an algorithm for computing the reliability of a circular consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system which claimed O(kn) time. J.S. Wu and R.J. Chen (1993) correctly pointed out that the algorithm achieved only O(kn/sup 2/) time. The present study shows that the algorithm can be implemented for O(kn) time.

references.text: F. K. Hwang, "An \${cal O}(kn)\$ -time algorithm for computing the reliability of a circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of- \$n\$:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., no. 1, pp. 161-162, Mar. 1993.

system

context.text: More precisely, people have been interested in computing efficiently the reliability of such systems in terms of the failure probabilities of each component (see [8]–[12][14], and references therein).

If one now considers a circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F system, then the Boolean function of the fault tree becomes It is well known (see [4], [9], [11], [12], or [1], Theorem 2 for the case of identical components) that the unreliability \$U_{C}(n)\$ of the circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F system can be expressed as a linear combination of the \$U_{L}(m)\$ for \$n-k\leq m\leq n-1\$.

links.abstract: The time complexities of previously published algorithms for circular consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems are O(nk/sup 2/) and O(nk). The authors propose a method to improve the original O(nk/sup 2/) algorithm, and hence derive an O(nk) algorithm.

references.text: J.-S. Wu, R.-J. Chen, "Efficient algorithm for reliability of a circular consecutive- \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 42, no. 1, pp. 163-164, Mar. 1993.

links.abstract: An O(k*n) algorithm is described for evaluating the reliability of a circular consecutive-k-out-n:F system.

references.text: J.-S. Wu, R.-J. Chen, "An \${cal O}(kn)\$ recursive algorithm for circular consecutive-\$k\$-out-of- \$n\$:F systems", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 41, pp. 303-305, 1992.

</ref_formula> algorithm for the consecutive-<ref_formula><tex>$k$</tex></ref_formula>-out-of-<ref_formula>

context.text: More precisely, people have been interested in computing efficiently the reliability of such systems in terms of the failure probabilities of each component (see [8]–[14], and references therein).

links.abstract: The fastest generally-recognized algorithms for computing the reliability of consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems require O(n) time, for both the linear and circular systems. The authors' new algorithm requires O(k/sup 3/spl middot/log(n/k)) time. The algorithm can be extended to yield an O(n/spl middot/max{k/sup 3/spl middot/log(n/k), log(n))} total time procedure for solving the combinatorial problem of counting the number of working states, with w working and n-w failed components, w=1,2,...,n.

references.text: F. K. Hwang, P. E. Wright, "An \${cal O}(k^{3}log(n/k))\$ algorithm for the consecutive-\$k\$-out-of- \$n\$:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 44, no. 1, pp. 128-131, Mar. 1995.

references.title:

<tex>$k$</tex></ref_formula>-out-of-<ref_formula><tex>$n$</tex></ref_formula>:F
systems

context.text: Furthermore, as it is remarked in [15], these algorithms do not allow one to compute the desired reliability within a reasonable execution time when \$k\$ and \$n\$ become large, even when the components are i.i.d. with the same failure probability.

references.text: M. Muselli, "New improved bounds for reliability of consecutive- \$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:F systems", J. Appl. Prob., vol. 37, pp. 1164-1170, 2000.

references.title: The fault-tree method

context.text: The unreliability of such systems can be expressed depending on the unreliability of systems with \$n-1,\ldots,n-k\$ components (see [8], Equation 1a. for example); this is straightforward by using probability arguments, but we show here that the corresponding linear recurrence equation of order \$k\$ can be recovered using Shannon decomposition [16].

This linear recurrence, given in Lemma 2 below, can be obtained directly using probability arguments (see [8], Equation 1a.); we propose here another approach using Shannon decomposition (see [16] for example).
To achieve the orthogonalization, we apply recursively Shannon decomposition (see [16] for example).
Once again, this relation can be recovered using Shannon decomposition techniques [16], and following exactly the same strategy as in the linear case; details are left to the reader.

links.abstract: This paper concerns the quantification of the fault tolerance of computer networks, where at least n-1 of the networks n nodes need to be intact and connected for mission success. The fault tree construction process is bottom up through 3 levels: i) point-to-point connectivity, ii) k-terminal connectivity, iii) "logical" combination of the connectivity of several clusters, such as for high-level tasks of parallel computing.

references.text: W. Schneeweiss, The fault-tree method, 1999, LiLoLe-Verlag.

references.title: An efficient formula for linear recurrences

context.text: The latter problem has been well studied in computer algebra (see [17], [18], and references therein), and it has been shown that this task can be performed using only \${\cal O}({\rm M}(k)\log(n)+k^{\omega})\$ 11The original result in [17] holds for the case of homogeneous recurrences, and the exponent of \$k\$ in the second summand is 2 instead of \$\omega\$.
The original result in [17] holds for the case of homogeneous recurrences, and the exponent of \$k\$ in the second summand is 2 instead of \$\omega\$.
This method is developed in [17], and the result is the following:.

However, comparing to the one defined in Section II, the square matrix \${\cal R}\$, say of size \$k\$, is no longer a companion matrix, so that, classically, we would use binary powering to compute its \$n\$th power in \${\cal O}(k^{\omega}\log(n))\$ operations (see [17], or [18], 2.3.4 for example).

references.text: C. M. Fiduccia, "An efficient formula for linear recurrences", SIAM J. Comput., no. 1, pp. 106-112, Feb. 1985.

references.title: Algorithmique efficace pour les oprations de base en calcul formel

context.text: The latter problem has been well studied in computer algebra (see [17], [18], and references therein), and it has been shown that this task can be performed using only \${\cal O}({\rm M}(k)\log(n)+k^{\omega})\$ 11The original result in [17] holds for the case of homogeneous recurrences, and the exponent of \$k\$ in the second summand is 2 instead of \$\omega\$.

The latter inverse, and product can both be computed using \${\cal O}(r^{\omega})\$ operations (see [20], [21], or [18], 2.3.1 for the complexity of computing the inverse) so that the complexity for computing \$\sum_{i=0}^{N-r}{\cal R}^{i}\$ is \${\cal O}({\rm M}(r)\log(N)+r^{\omega})\$.

However, comparing to the one defined in Section II, the square matrix \${\cal R}\$, say of size \$k\$, is no longer a companion matrix, so that, classically, we would use binary powering to compute its \$n\$th power in \${\cal O}(k^{\omega}\log(n))\$ operations (see [17], or [18], 2.3.4 for example).

Indeed, there exists a Las Vegas type probabilistic algorithm for computing the \$n\$th power of a square matrix of size \$k\$ in only \${\cal O}((k+\log(n)){\rm M}(k)+k^{\omega}\log(k))\$ operations (see [23], Corollary 6.4, or [18], 2.3.4), so that by using it, we manage to provide an algorithm in \${\cal O}((k+\log(n)){\rm M}(k)+k^{\omega}\log(k))\$ for computing \$U_{n}\$.

references.text: A. Bostan, Algorithmique efficace pour les oprations de base en calcul formel, 2003, cole Polytechnique.

references.title: Modern computer algebra

context.text: The result for the non-homogeneous case is easily deduced in Section II-B below. operations in the base field where \${\rm M}(k)\$ is the number of operations needed to multiply two polynomials of degree at most \$k\$, and \$2<\omega<3\$ is the exponent of linear algebra or matrix multiplication exponent defined such that the number of operations needed to multiply two square matrices of size \$k\$ is \${\cal O}(k^{\omega})\$ [19], 12.1.
Using the Fast Fourier Transform, we further have \${\rm M}(k)={\cal O}(k\log(k)\log(\log(k)))\$ [19], 12.1 so that we obtain the complexity estimate announced.
Note that the latter product can be computed using only \${\cal O}(r^{2})\$ operations [19].
The result then follows because a product matrix-vector of size \$r\$ can be computed in \${\cal O}(r^{2})\$ operations, and \$2<\omega<3\$ [19].\$\hfill\blackbox\$.
For the last assertion of the theorem, we use the fact that the Fast Fourier Transform corresponds to \${\rm M}(k)=k\log(k)\log(\log(k))\$ [19], 8.2–8.3.
The second assertion of the theorem is clear as the Fast Fourier Transform corresponds to \${\rm M}(k)=k\log(k)\log(\log(k))\$ [19], 8.2–8.3. \$\hfill\blackbox\$.

references.text: J. von zur Gathen, J. Gerhard, Modern computer algebra, 1999, Cambridge University Press.

context.text: Note that the same improvement is obtained for computing the (un)reliability of consecutive-\$k\$-out-of-\$n\$:G systems [22], Lemma 1.

links.abstract: A consecutive-k-out-of-n:F (consecutive-k-out-of-n:G) system consists of an ordered sequence of n components such that the system is failed (good) if and only if at least k consecutive components in the system are failed (good). In the present work, the relationship between the consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system and the consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system is studied, theorems for such systems are developed, and available results for one type of system are applied to the other. The topics include system...

references.text: W. Kuo, W. Zhang, M. Zuo, "A consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system: The mirror image of a consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 39, no. 2, pp. 244-253, 1990.

references.title:
Nearly optimal algorithms for canonical
matrix form

references.text: M. Giesbrecht, "Nearly optimal algorithms for canonical matrix form", SIAM J. Comput., no. 5, pp. 948-969, 1995.
